byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, Marlise Simons from The Hague, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA, MARLISE SIMONS and ANNE BARNARD

abstract: International inspectors are said to have found evidence of banned toxic chemicals in at least three military areas in Syria; government forces are accused of continuing to bomb insurgent-occupied areas with chlorine bombs.
lead_paragraph: The discovery came as Syrian government forces were being accused of continuing to bombard insurgent-held areas with chlorine bombs.

headline.main: Inspectors in Syria Find Traces of Banned Military Chemicals
headline.print_headline: Inspectors in Syria Find Traces of Banned Military Chemicals

snippet: The discovery came as Syrian government forces were being accused of continuing to bombard insurgent-held areas with chlorine bombs.

keywords.value: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
keywords.name: organizations
